message: Judge Gorsuch is a well-qualified, independent, and mainstream Supreme Court nominee. He has a long history of interpreting the law faithfully, thoughtfully and consistently, and I look forward to confirming him next week.
Susan and I wish you a Happy New Year!
Congratulations to my good friend Senator Richard Burr on being sworn in for his third term! I look forward to continuing our work to serve the people of North Carolina.

In 2016, I worked with VA Secretary Robert McDonald and my Senate colleagues on the MyVa initiative to transform the VA into a more efficient, customer service-oriented organization that delivers top-notch health care services to veterans.
Premiums are soaring, patients’ choices are dwindling. Obamacare must be repealed and replaced. #RepealObamacare
Two years ago, I was sworn in as North Carolina's U.S. Senator. It's been an honor to serve North Carolinians, and I look forward to continuing to work on behalf of each of you.

I had the honor of meeting with General James Mattis to discuss his nomination for Secretary of Defense. I was encouraged to hear his views on increasing departmental transparency, and look forward to working with him as we continue to make our fighting force the best trained, equipped, and ready force in the world.
Monday, January 9 is the deadline to apply for federal disaster assistance from Hurricane Matthew. Register with FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency online: https://www.disasterassistance.gov/
Please continue to keep Senator Kay Hagan and her family in your thoughts and prayers. Susan and I are praying she makes a full recovery.
Please be safe, stay warm and avoid travel if possible. Thank you to the crews working around the clock to clear the roadways.
Tune in to Fox News at 10:10am where I will be speaking to Maria Bartiromo about cyber security and the upcoming nomination hearings.

I am saddened to hear the news out of Orlando. This is another tragic reminder of the dangers our law enforcement officers face every single day.   Today, on National Law Enforcement Day, please take a moment to thank an officer for their service.

Deadline extended – January 23 is the new deadline to apply for federal disaster assistance from Hurricane Matthew. Register with FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency online: https://www.disasterassistance.gov/

Read my op-ed with U.S. Senator Chris Coons about the need to reform our nation's broken criminal justice system. We share a belief that the focus is far too much on criminalization and incarceration and too little on rehabilitation.  via CNN Opinion

Are you or someone you know interested in an internship in one of my offices? Congressional internships offer students a unique opportunity to observe and participate in the workings of the United States Congress. The application process is now open for legislative, communications and judicial internships.  Apply online: tillis.senate.gov
My statement on President-elect Trump’s nominee for Secretary of Veterans Affairs, Dr. David Shulkin.

This morning, the Senate passed the Obamacare repeal resolution that allows the Senate to begin the repeal and replace process. In delivering our promise to the American people, we'll now be able to fully repeal Obamacare and replace it with personalized, patient-centered health care that is affordable for everyone.
Read my latest newsletter and sign-up to receive updates from my office at tillis.senate.gov.

My wife, Susan, had the honor of presenting former State Rep. Larry Womble a copy of the eugenics compensation bill that I introduced in the Senate and President Obama signed into law. This federal law was made possible because of Rep. Womble's tireless pursuit in seeking justice for eugenics victims in North Carolina.   President Obama signed the bill into law in October 2016: http://bit.ly/EugenicsCompensation

On Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, we celebrate the life and legacy of a man who changed history by leading the fight for freedom and opportunity for all Americans. We are a better nation and a better people because of Dr. King's inspirational leadership of the Civil Rights Movement and his courage in challenging America to live up to its full potential.
‪Grateful to spend MLK Day doing a ‬service project at High Point University with United Apparel packing blessing bags for homeless veterans.‬

Let’s be clear: the American people didn’t give the GOP a stamp of approval or a mandate to ram through an ideologically-driven, far-right agenda. If the election was a mandate for anything, it was for elected officials in both parties to break through the gridlock to finally start producing results.
I will be hosting a Facebook Live Townhall TOMORROW at 2:30pm. Please submit your questions in the comments below, and I look forward to speaking with you on Wednesday.
Answering your questions live. Thanks for joining.

Congratulations to Donald J. Trump on becoming the 45th President of the United States of America. I wish him the best and I am going to work hard to produce the results the American people trusted us to produce when they elected Republicans last November. I look forward to serving with him.
It's shameful that rioters are destroying fellow citizens' property and displaying open contempt for our nation's tradition of a peaceful transfer of power.

January 23, 2017 is the deadline for North Carolinians affected by Hurricane Matthew to register for disaster assistance from FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency. I encourage all those who sustained property damage to apply.

I am heartbroken to learn of the passing of my dear friend Ruth Samuelson this morning. Ruth was a wonderful wife and mother. She was a great leader who was so dedicated to making our world better. I will miss her so much. God rest her blessed soul in the Kingdom of Heaven.

It is time to break the congressional gridlock and solve the immigration problem that has plagued our nation for decades. We must put forward a bipartisan plan to tighten border security, toughen enforcement of immigration laws, and address the fate of the roughly 11 million illegal immigrants currently in the U.S. via The Wall Street Journal

Today, North Carolina received more than $198 million in federal assistance from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development for Hurricane Matthew recovery. In December, I worked with appropriators and my colleagues to secure more than $300 million in assistance, which will help families and communities affected by Hurricane Matthew.

Today is a sad day as we say goodbye to former Rep. Ruth Samuelson. She was a dear friend to Susan and me, and she will be greatly missed. Please continue to lift her family up in prayer.  This photo is from the NC General Assembly's Brims & Bows day in 2013.
My statement on President Trump's immigration executive order.
The News & Record highlighted my framework for a broad immigration overhaul in its latest editorial.

I joined Senators Shaheen​ (D-NH) & McCaskill (D-MO) to send a letter to Secretary of Defense James Mattis following President Trump’s immigration executive order. In the letter, we expressed concern about the harmful impact that this policy has on Iraqis who provided essential support to the U.S. mission in Iraq.

Judge Neil Gorsuch is an incredibly qualified and mainstream choice to serve on the Supreme Court. He has proven himself to be a judge who approaches every case before him with fairness, and bases his decisions on the rule of law. I hope my colleagues in the Senate, regardless of party, will join me in thoughtfully considering Judge Gorsuch as our next Supreme Court Justice.
This February, I join my fellow North Carolinians to celebrate and reflect on the African-American history and heritage in our state and across the country.

Last night, I delivered a Senate floor speech calling on my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to cast aside the political fringes and work together in order to produce results for the American people.   It's time to get past the election results, get over it and get to work. It's time to recognize that real people sent a mandate, but the mandate wasn't Republican, wasn’t far-right, wasn’t far-left. All they said was produce results. I'm going to produce results. I'm going to expect my members to produce results. I’m going to go into my conference when it looks like we’re going down the path that doesn't produce a result and I’m going to call them out, and I’ll hold my colleagues on the other side of the aisle to the same standard.

Are you a college student interested in observing and participating in the workings of the United States Senate while assisting North Carolinians? A limited number of internships which start immediately are available in my North Carolina offices. Apply Online: https://www.tillis.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/internships
10 Places to Explore African-American History in North Carolina. #BlackHistoryMonth   via Visit North Carolina

I joined a bipartisan group of senators to send a letter to President Donald J. Trump, calling for greater investment in Alzheimer’s research. If nothing is done to change the trajectory of Alzheimer’s, the number of Americans afflicted with the disease is expected to more than triple by 2050. #ENDALZ   Read the letter: http://bit.ly/2kkYR7F

I introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Klobuchar to help veterans who have been exposed to toxic burn pits. The Helping Veterans Exposed to Burn Pits Act would create a center of excellence within the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to better understand the health effects associated with burn pits and treat veterans who become sick after exposure.

Tonight, the Senate voted to confirm Senator Jeff Sessions as our next Attorney General. While we certainly don’t agree on the specifics of every major issue, including immigration reform and criminal justice reform, he will follow the rule of law, be accessible, and address the organizational and accountability issues plaguing the Department of Justice.

Yesterday, I had a very productive meeting with Judge Gorsuch, who is going to make a great Supreme Court justice. I agree with my colleagues on the other side of the aisle: he has impressive credentials, academically, on the bench, and as a litigator. We look forward to having him confirmed as the ninth Supreme Court justice very soon.
Check out the 82nd Airborne Division's feature on our nation's first all-black airborne unit known as the Triple Nickle. #BlackHistoryMonth

Over the weekend, I joined Fox News to discuss my framework for bipartisan immigration reform. I have been meeting with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to discuss solutions to secure our borders and fix America’s broken immigration system. Read more about my framework at http://bit.ly/2k3yhk8.

I was proud to support Dr. Shulkin in his confirmation as the VA Secretary. His experience running complex healthcare systems combined with his experience in the VA make him the right leader to go about solving the problems in the VA. I look forward to working with him in my capacity as a Veterans’ Affairs committee member.

I joined Senator Tammy Baldwin​ to introduce the BRAVE Act, bipartisan legislation that would support job creation for America’s veterans. The men and women who served in our military bring tremendous leadership capabilities and work ethic to the private sector and I am proud to increase employment opportunities for our veterans.
There needs to be a culture where it’s OK to say the military shouldn’t be imposing these hardships, such as a family paying $15,000 to stay behind for a child’s education.
I enjoyed meeting with athlete Kristine Hughes and Special Olympics NC on Wednesday! #SOHillDay
Read my latest e-newsletter and sign up to receive updates from my office: https://www.tillis.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/newsletter-signup
With U.S. Customs and Border Protection in Texas.

It's great to see North Carolinian, Nancy White, named a 2017 Dole Caregiver Fellow by the Elizabeth Dole Foundation. I congratulate and thank Nancy for her work and wish her well as she works to expand public knowledge of the mental health issues facing wounded warriors and their caregivers. #HiddenHeroes

Earlier this week, I traveled to Texas as part of a congressional delegation to gain firsthand knowledge of the challenges facing our country and those who are protecting our border. I had the opportunity to learn more about the law enforcement and public safety challenges on the border and heard from federal and immigration court judges about their expansive caseload. The safety and interests of North Carolinians, the experiences of the people I spoke with on this trip, and the integrity of our nation’s security will continue to guide my work on the important issues of border security and immigration reform.

I am proud of the graduates celebrating their victory over substance abuse and addiction, and grateful to TROSA: Triangle Residential Options for Substance Abusers for helping these individuals recover. I had the privilege of visiting TROSA last year to see first-hand how I can assist non-profit organizations like TROSA to continue helping people turn their lives around and get a second chance at fulfilling their dreams.

The multiple bomb threats against Jewish Community Centers in Charlotte, Asheville and across the nation are profoundly disturbing, and I hope federal law enforcement quickly brings the perpetrators to justice. Anti-Semitism has no place in our society. We will always be a nation that proudly cherishes the freedom of religion, where Christians, Jews, Muslims and all others are free to practice, teach, and observe their faiths.

I will greatly miss Ray’s tremendous leadership, his warm sense of humor, and his genuine passion for working on behalf of all North Carolinians. Ray has been a lifelong champion for North Carolina’s agricultural industry, and he will now play a major role in fulfilling the administration’s plans to support our nation’s farmers and ranchers and revitalize rural America. I wish him and his family all the best in this new and exciting chapter, and I look forward to working closely with him to advocate for our state’s agricultural and rural communities.
My statement following President Donald J. Trump’s address to a joint session of Congress.
This week, I met with North Carolina veterans from the American Legion.

This morning, I had the chance to go on Varney & Co. to discuss my recent trip to the southern border, the need for immigration reform, and the necessity for bipartisan reforms to our healthcare system.

I am focused on making healthcare more available to veterans through both the private and public sector. We do not want to privatize the VA, but instead, empower the VA, and I look forward to working with the American Legion and all of the stakeholders so we can solve the problems plaguing the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.
It was great to meet leaders from North Carolina HBCUs. Thank you, Representative Mark Walker and Senator Tim Scott for hosting this event!
This morning, I had the privilege of welcoming Chaplain Sharad Creasman from Brevard, NC to open the Senate in prayer.

Earlier this week, the Senate Judiciary Committee held a hearing to discuss how to improve outcomes for youth in the Juvenile Justice System. As both U.S. Senator and North Carolina House Speaker, I have been a longtime champion for bipartisan reforms to the juvenile justice system and juvenile delinquency.

Are you or someone you know interested in an internship in one of my offices? Congressional internships offer students the opportunity to learn about the workings of the U.S. Senate while assisting with casework, research, and constituent services. My offices are accepting applications for summer internships until March 31.

Tonight at 6:00pm, I will be hosting a live telephone town hall, where I’ll have a conversation with North Carolinians about important issues facing our state and country. Click on the link below to listen in and if you would like to leave a message or ask a question, please submit an email on my website.
My statement on Congress’ efforts to repeal Obamacare and reform the nation’s broken health care system.

Last week, I participated in an immigration roundtable hosted by the Bipartisan Policy Center where I highlighted my immigration reform framework and the potential path forward. Watch the roundtable discussion by clicking the link below.

This week, I joined all 99 of my Senate colleagues to urge the Trump Administration to take action in response to the recent anonymous bomb threats made against Jewish Community Centers (JCC’s), Jewish Day Schools, and Synagogues. These institutions play an important role within their communities and we must do everything we can to deter the threats of violence.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to meet Ronald King, an Eagle Scout from the Cape Fear Council - Boy Scouts of America. He's one of ten youth delegates from across the country who joined Boy Scouts of America to deliver the "Report to the Nation" to President Donald J. Trump.  #BSA2016RTN #BSAImpact

Congratulations to Duke Men's Basketball, North Carolina Central University, UNC Basketball, UNCW Men's Basketball, and Wake Forest University for being selected to play in this year's NCAA Tournament!

During today’s Senate Armed Services Committee hearing, I questioned General Robert Neller, Commandant of the Marine Corps, about misconduct on the “Marines United” website. I have confidence that swift and appropriate action will be taken to seek justice for those who have been victimized. However, it is important to stress that the reprehensible conduct of some is not a reflection of the vast majority of Marines who serve and defend our nation with honor and distinction.

I joined a bipartisan group of Senators, including the leadership of the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs, to send a letter to Secretary of Veterans Affairs David Shulkin in response to a troubling Inspector General report earlier this month on veteran wait times. Across the Mid-Atlantic Healthcare Network (VISN 6) actual wait times were drastically different than what has been reported by VA medical facilities, including locations in Asheville, Durham, Fayetteville, and Salisbury.

Today, I welcomed students and teachers from the Shining Light Baptist Academy to my D.C. office.   North Carolinians planning a trip to D.C., please reach out to my office at https://www.tillis.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/visiting-dc.

I joined a bipartisan group of senators to show our support in protecting and encouraging whistleblowers who shine light on fraud, waste and abuse in our government. We aim to create a culture that welcomes whistleblowers and protects their rights from attacks.

I'm proud to introduce bipartisan legislation that will authorize additional visas for Afghans to apply for refuge in the U.S. These visas will go to many brave Afghans who have risked their lives in order to support American troops and their efforts to defeat terrorists.

I had the opportunity to meet with Michael Yang, a student at Charlotte Latin School. Michael was a finalist in the Regeneron Science Talent Search, the nation's most prestigious pre-college science competition. Michael is a leader of the up-and-coming generation of STEM researchers, and I applaud his hard work and passion. #RegeneronSTS
I am thankful the day has finally come that veterans affected by contaminated water at Camp Lejeune are now receiving compensation from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.

My office is accepting applications until March 31 for summer internships in North Carolina and Washington, D.C. Congressional internships offer students the opportunity to learn about the workings of the U.S. Senate while assisting with casework, research, and constituent services.
NA
Please keep Officer Freeman's family and the Southport community in your thoughts and prayers.
Congratulations to the North Carolina Tar Heels on advancing to the #Sweet16!
I joined Maria Bartiromo on Fox News to discuss the hearings for SCOTUS nominee Neil Gorsuch. Follow the Senate Judiciary Committee for live coverage from the hearings.
Watch Live: Day 1 of the hearings on #SCOTUS nominee Judge Neil Gorsuch.

During today's Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on the nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, I spoke in favor of Judge Gorsuch’s impressive qualifications and track record of being a mainstream and independent-minded jurist.

My op-ed on Fox News.com recapping #SCOTUS Nominee Neil Gorsuch’s confirmation hearing and calling on Democrats to not resort to a politically-motivated filibuster of such an eminently qualified nominee.   via Fox News Opinion
The deadline to apply for an internship in my office is approaching. Apply online at https://www.tillis.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/internships.
Pray for the safety of the 82nd Airborne Division and all of our troops deployed.

Last week, I introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) to cut out-of-pocket costs for National Guard Members and Reservists traveling to training and drills.  12,000 citizen soldiers fill the ranks of the North Carolina Army National Guard and North Carolina Air National Guard.

It was great to meet with the Alzheimer's Association-Western Carolina visiting Washington, D.C. Each year, the Alzheimer's Association has an Advocacy Day on Capitol Hill to discuss Alzheimer's Disease, its impact on their lives, and legislative solutions to #ENDALZ. As a caregiver to a loved one who battled Alzheimer's Disease, I will continue to fight to end Alzheimer's.
My statement on the North Carolina General Assembly's vote to repeal House Bill 2.

This week, the Senate Special Committee on Aging held a hearing on the state of Alzheimer’s disease. I’ve been a strong advocate for investing in Alzheimer’s research and providing support for caregivers. I look forward to continuing to support efforts to find a cure. #EndALZ
Joining Autism Speaks to #LightItUpBlue for World Autism Awareness Day!

Last week, I joined Senator Richard Burr, Senator Bill Nelson and Senator Marco Rubio, to introduce The Janey Ensminger Act of 2017, which requires the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to provide medical care for all diseases that can be scientifically linked to exposure to toxic chemicals at Camp Lejeune.
Please join me on Wednesday for a Facebook Q&A. I'll be taking your questions live at 12pm ET.

The H-2B program is vital to small and seasonal employers across the country who depend on temporary workers to sustain their businesses and supplement their existing American workforce. This bipartisan legislation would streamline the program to eliminate ambiguities and establish clear parameters for employers hiring H-2B workers, require increased coordination between federal agencies, and bring transparency to the program operations for greater efficiency while ensuring American workers are not displaced.
Congratulations to the North Carolina Tar Heels on winning the National Championship!

Judge Gorsuch is a supremely qualified and mainstream nominee who deserves an up-or-down vote on his confirmation. I urge Senate Democrats to maintain a nearly 230-year old precedent of confirming Supreme Court nominees by a simple majority vote.
Join me for a live question and answer session.
Earlier today, I joined Fox News to discuss the Democrats’ filibuster of Judge Neil Gorusch and the need for Republicans and Democrats to work together on bipartisan solutions in the Senate.

My statement following the U.S. military’s airstrikes in Syria:  Assad is a war criminal who has targeted and murdered his own people, including innocent children. President Trump decisively responded to Assad’s latest atrocity to help prevent future ones, sending a clear message that when the Syrian regime crosses the red line, America will respond. We owe a debt of gratitude to the brave men and women in uniform who carried out today’s mission and continue to keep our nation safe and secure.
Congratulations, Judge Neil Gorsuch, our next Supreme Court Justice!

This week, I had the chance to meet with many North Carolinians visiting D.C. I met with students from Village Christian Academy, St. John's Lutheran School, HBCU Democracy Fellows and families from Greensboro and Elon.
Please keep Maj. Gen. Espaillat, his family, and those who served with him, in your thoughts and prayers. I am grateful to him for his service to our country in the U.S. Army Reserve.

Senator Gary Peters and I led a bipartisan group of Senators in a letter calling for increased funding to support the advancement of connected and automated vehicle (CAV) technologies. Connected and self-driving cars can dramatically reduce the more than 35,000 lives lost on our roads and highways every year and fundamentally transform the way we get around.

I recently joined a bipartisan group of Senators in writing to Senate leadership and urging them to leave the legislative filibuster intact and preserve the 60 vote threshold for legislation.   The Senate plays an important role in the legislative process, and I am committed to ensuring that this great American institution continues to serve as the world’s greatest deliberative body by opposing any effort to curtail the existing rights and prerogatives of Senators to engage in full, robust, and extended debate as we consider legislation before this body in the future.
Happy Easter from my family to yours!

Today, I joined NFIB NC for Small Business Day, discussed cybersecurity and veterans programs at Wake Technical Community College, and chatted with The 4th Down Foundation about the next generation developing the leadership skills needed for this great nation.
Last week, I visited C.E. Barnes Store, in Clayton! This family owned business was founded in 1927.

A great day in North Carolina where I met three veterans who started Southern Pines Brewing Company, military spouses who support the brave men and women fighting for our freedoms through their business R. Riveter, and finishing the day with a visit to Fort Bragg, N.C. Thank you to our nation's veterans, those currently serving, and the families of these men and women for your service and sacrifice.
My op-ed on the need to secure our nation's border as one of the first steps to reforming our broken immigration system.  via The Hill
Yesterday, Senator Richard Burr and I visited Fort Bragg, N.C., where we met with Paratroopers assigned to the 3rd Brigade Combat Team, 82nd Airborne Division.

Last week, I met with students and leaders at Wake Technical Community College to discuss the cybersecurity training and veterans programs offered. Wake Tech has a variety of programs and services for our nation's veterans.

Chechnya officials are kidnapping and torturing gay men. I condemn this gross violation of human rights. The leader of Chechnya is a Putin loyalist, and no surprise Putin is denying that these shameful human rights violations are taking place.
NA

On Tuesday at 5:30pm, I'll be hosting a live telephone town hall, where I’ll have a conversation with North Carolinians about important issues facing our state and country. Click on the link below to listen in.  *The time is subject to change due to the Senate schedule. We'll keep you updated with any changes to the time.
Congratulations, Secretary Perdue, on your confirmation as Secretary of Agriculture. Your knowledge and passion for agriculture will be great for North Carolina and the whole country.
Last night, I joined Tucker Carlson Tonight on Fox News where I discussed the most effective ways to secure the United States’ Southern border.

I am proud to be selected as a member of the U.S. Helsinki Commission, an independent government agency that monitors compliance with the Helsinki Accords and comprehensive security through promotion of human rights, democracy, and economic, environmental, and military cooperation in the 57-nation OSCE region.
Saturday is the DEA's Prescription Drug Take-Back Day. Find the closest location to safely dispose of your unused prescription drugs.

Shocked to learn about the passing of Mark Binker, a truly great guy who also happened to be an outstanding journalist. Please keep your thoughts and prayers with Mark's family during this incredibly difficult time.

Providing top-notch constituent services has always been my top priority as your senator. My office has closed nearly 10,000 cases for North Carolinians who were having issues with the federal government, including the VA, Social Security Administration, IRS, the Department of Health and Human Services, and the Citizenship and Immigration Services, among others. If you or someone you know is having any trouble with a federal agency, please make sure your next call is to one of my offices.
Last month, I joined a bipartisan group of Senators in writing to Senate leadership and urging them to leave the legislative filibuster intact and preserve the 60 vote threshold for legislation.
We should leave the Senate's legislative filibuster intact. 60 votes = bipartisanship required. That's a good thing.

I welcomed Zoe & Madeline, twins from North Carolina, to my office during their visit to Capitol Hill with ZERO TO THREE. This organization focuses on knowledge and know-how to nurture early development for infants and toddlers.  #ThinkBabies #StrollingThunder
NA
A great story from Cabarrus County Schools' Northwest Carrabus High School and Dream On 3. Enjoy watching the New York Yankees, Christian!

This week is Teacher Appreciation Week. There are tens of thousands of teachers across the state of North Carolina. Their work inspiring and educating students is a critical and challenging job. I thank teachers throughout North Carolina for their hard work and encourage others to #ThankATeacher.

I’m proud to work with Senator Gary Peters in leading a bipartisan group of our colleagues to support robust funding for State Veterans Homes that help provide long-term care to our nation’s veterans.

I am proud to co-sponsored The Veterans Overmedication Prevention Act, bipartisan legislation that would direct the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to conduct an independent expert study on the deaths of all veterans being treated at the VA who died by suicide or from a drug overdose in the last five years.

Today, I voted in favor of the FY17 Omnibus Appropriations bill, which funds key national and North Carolina priorities. While not perfect, this bipartisan legislation takes key steps to bolster our national security, including increasing defense spending to rebuild our military and providing more funds to help secure our border.
On National Nurses Day, I send my thanks to nurses across North Carolina, including my daughter Lindsay, for their dedication to the vital work they do.
Now that the House has passed the AHCA, the Senate will get to work to make major changes and improve the legislation.

Today, my staff attended the 2017 Law Day Celebration and Peace Officers Memorial Day in Cabarrus County and presented a flag flown over the U.S. Capital to Captain Patrick N. Patty, recipient of the Robert J. Eury Award. Captain Patty has served 22 years in law enforcement, and previously served in the US Army as an infantry soldier with the 82nd Airborne Divison.  The award is the highest honor an officer can receive in Cabarrus County. The award is in memory of Robert J. Eury who was killed in the line of duty in 1972.
Last week, I joined a bipartisan group of 15 senators in urging President Trump to prioritize advocacy for democracy and respect for human rights in the administration’s foreign policy agenda.
We owe a debt of gratitude to our servicemembers and veterans. Join me in saying thanks to the men and women who serve our great nation. #MilitaryAppreciationMonth
Congratulations to Dr. Heather Wilson on her confirmation as Secretary of the United States Air Force.
Please join me this Thursday for a Facebook Q&A. I'll be answering your questions live at 5:15pm.

Congratulations to Victoria Kosinski of Kinston and Caleb Lumpkin of Winston-Salem, the 2017 North Carolina Honorees for The Prudential Spirit of Community Awards. Victoria's outstanding work for women who are victims of domestic violence and Caleb's dedication to helping those with intellectual disabilities makes the state a better place. #PruSpirit2017
Please post your questions below for the Facebook Live Q&A.

Attention Veterans: Be aware of a Veterans Choice Program phone line imposter that is trying to steal personal information. The correct number is 1-866-606-8198.   Follow U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for updates and additional information.

Saddened to hear of the sudden passing of my friend Rudy Wright. Mayor Wright was a fierce advocate for the city and people of Hickory, which he served for nearly two decades. Our thoughts and prayers are with Donna and his family.

This week, I spoke on the Senate Floor about the Senate’s recent success in repealing 14 burdensome regulations under the Congressional Review Act. Over the past couple of months, we reduced the regulatory burden by $67 billion and eliminated an estimated 56 million paperwork hours.

Happy Mother's Day to these three amazing mothers and one soon-to-be! Our family is thankful to each of them for their unconditional love and support.  To my mother Margie, thank you for being strong and kind, and being such a big part of all of our lives and the lives of our children. Thank you for all that you have done to make me who I am. I love you!

Today marks the beginning of National Police Week, a time to reflect on the men and women in law enforcement who have made the ultimate sacrifice and thank those who protect our communities every single day. I want you all to know how much we appreciate the job you do for us. God bless our nation's law enforcement. #NationalPoliceWeek

I had the honor of meeting with the Huntersville Police Department and NC State Highway Patrol. I am proud of our brave law enforcement officials, and I will continue to do everything I can to ensure they have the support and resources they need to stay safe while protecting and serving all North Carolinians. #NationalPoliceWeek
I'm doing well. Looking forward to getting back to work. Thanks for all of your prayers and well wishes.

After receiving a good bill of health, I returned to work on Capitol Hill. I'm incredibly grateful to the good Samaritans who assisted me at the race and the medical professionals at the hospital. Thank you for all the prayers and well wishes.
I'm joining Bo Thompson on WBT's Morning News today at 8:05am. http://www.wbt.com
My statement on the selection of Robert Mueller as special counsel.

Gain firsthand knowledge of the workings of Congress while helping North Carolinians. Congressional internships offer students a unique opportunity to conduct legislative research, attend committee hearings, and assist with constituent correspondence. The application deadline for Fall legislative, communications and judicial internships is approaching.  Apply online: tillis.senate.gov

This week, I co-sponsored the Back the Blue Act of 2017, legislation that would increase the penalties for criminals who intentionally target law enforcement officers, and provide new tools for officers to protect themselves. These brave men and women risk their lives to protect ours, and this legislation will make criminals think twice before targeting them.
Today, and every day, we honor the men and women of our Armed Forces and thank them for their service to our country. #ArmedForcesDay
Last week, Senator Richard Burr and I met with The ALS Association.
Today, I attended a roundtable discussion on immigration reform at the Greater Raleigh Chamber of Commerce.  via The News & Observer

On this Memorial Day, I hope you'll take a moment to reflect on the men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice in defense of our freedoms. I hope you'll also take the opportunity to thank a man or woman in uniform because they, like those who served before them, are prepared to do everything they must to keep us safe. Have a wonderful Memorial Day and God bless.

This evening at 5:30 pm, Senator Richard Burr will join me to host a live telephone town hall, where we’ll have a conversation with North Carolinians about important issues facing our state and country. Beginning at 5:30 pm, click on the link below to submit a question and listen live.  *The time is subject to change due to the Senate schedule. We'll keep you updated with any changes to the time.

Our unsecure border is a humanitarian crisis regardless of how you feel about border security. These are people crossing the border illegally who are dying because we don’t have the right mix of people, technology and infrastructure in place to save them.

I joined a bipartisan group of senators to fight against genocide and other human rights atrocities around the world. The Elie Wiesel Genocide and Atrocities Prevention Act of 2017 detects early warning signs of human rights atrocities and helps fulfill the United States’ promise to genocide survivors to prevent future genocides.

I joined a bipartisan coalition to help states in renewing and maintaining their outdated infrastructure. The BRIDGE Act is a bipartisan, commonsense solution that will help North Carolina and states across the country utilize private funds for building and maintaining important infrastructure.
NA

News that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of NC Affordable Care Act rates may increase by almost 23% in 2018 is proof that Obamacare isn’t working. We need reform that eliminates skyrocketing premiums, creates more choices, and works to address the millions of Americans with preexisting conditions.

I'm proud to announce the new integrated military-civilian trauma system at Camp Lejeune. I look forward to working closely with health care leaders as we enhance the abilities and delivery of health care at the Naval Medical Center Camp Lejeune to better respond to the needs of both military personnel and civilians in Eastern North Carolina.

The joint military-civilian trauma system will be the first pilot program of its kind in the nation and will bring a number of critical benefits, including significantly reducing the transit times for many civilian trauma patients who live in areas between Greenville and Wilmington.  via StarNews

Senator Amy Klobuchar and I led a bipartisan group of senators in calling for Pentagon funding and research of burn bit exposure. More than 100,000 military personnel who served in Iraq and Afghanistan have signed up for the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs burn pit exposure registry.

I recently co-sponsored the Cannabidiol Research Expansion Act, a commonsense, bipartisan effort to remove unnecessary barriers to give researchers an improved ability to study the potential benefits and risks of cannabidiol and other components that are derived from the marijuana plant.

I applaud the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for taking a vital step in the modernization of the Electronic Health Record system and addressing a problem that has been a consistent detriment to our veterans.

My statement on the Senate health care draft:  Health care is a critically important issue that affects every single American, and I’ve heard countless stories from North Carolinians who have had their lives upended by Obamacare, from hardworking parents unable to afford skyrocketing premiums to insure their families to small business owners who have been forced to cut hours or even let go of employees because of the law’s costly mandates. As I’ve said repeatedly, any replacement plan must be a net improvement over Obamacare, and I look forward to carefully reviewing the draft legislation over the next several days.
This bipartisan legislation will give the VA the long-overdue authority to remove bad actors and put the people in place we need to give veterans the care they need and deserve.

My statement on Attorney General Jeff Sessions:  “I’ve worked with Jeff Sessions for years, and while we certainly may not agree on the specifics of every issue, I believed he would be a great Attorney General because of his unwavering commitment to the rule of law. In the nearly six months he has led the Department of Justice, he has maintained that commitment every day and demonstrated why he was widely respected during his years as a U.S. Senator.   While some may argue that he should not have recused himself from the Russia investigation, Attorney General Sessions demonstrated good judgement by doing so and removed all appearances of a potential conflict. The Attorney General’s recusal was ultimately made in the best interests of the Department of Justice and the country.  Following eight years of organizational and accountability issues plaguing the Department of Justice, Attorney General Sessions’ leadership is needed now more than ever.”

My statement after voting in favor of the motion to proceed, beginning a debate on legislation to repeal Obamacare and reform America’s health care system:   Over the last several years, Obamacare has hit hardworking North Carolina families with skyrocketing premiums and fewer choices, while small businesses have struggled to comply with the law’s costly and burdensome regulations. The status quo of Obamacare is unsustainable, and today’s procedural vote sets the stage for an open amendment process where all Senators – Republicans and Democrats alike – will be able to put forward their ideas to reform our nation’s health care system.   The motion to proceed, which is offered to bring a piece of legislation or other legislative measure up for consideration and debate. The motion to proceed passed 51-50, initiating the start of debate and an open amendment process over the coming days.

I joined fellow Senators in calling for the U.S. Department of Labor to clear the path for implementation of 401(k) auto portability that would make it easier for Americans to save for their future. To simplify retirement, we must let American’s take the lead in being in charge of their savings.

My statement on the health care reform vote:  The majority of members of Congress made a promise to the American people to repeal and replace Obamacare with solutions that will help control the cost of premiums and provide more choices and flexibility for families and individuals. While today’s vote was unsuccessful, we cannot accept the status quo as Obamacare continues down an unsustainable path, and Congress has an obligation to keep pursuing solutions to fix our nation’s broken health care system.

I joined a bipartisan group of senators to call on Acting Federal Bureau of Prisons Director Thomas Kane and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein to review and explain their plans to follow recommendations from the Department of Justice Inspector General to expand the use of compassionate release, a program that provides low-risk, elderly or terminally ill inmates the opportunity to appeal for early release if they meet specific criteria.

My statement following President Trump’s speech on America’s strategy in Afghanistan and South Asia:   For nearly two decades, America’s finest–our brave men and women in uniform–have risked and sacrificed their lives in the global effort to rid the world of radical jihadist terrorism. While we have made significant progress, we cannot afford Afghanistan to now be turned into a safe haven for ISIS, Al-Qaeda, and the Taliban. I applaud the President for clearly defining America’s objectives in Afghanistan and South Asia, which will help promote peace and stability in the region and ultimately make us safer here at home.
North Carolina is the proud home of the 82nd Airborne Division. Thank you for 100 years of service! Here's to 100 more. #AllTheWay

My statement on President Trump's speech on tax reform:  I applaud President Trump for laying out principles for tax reform that include simplifying the tax code, cutting rates, and producing economic growth. In 2013, North Carolina passed historic tax reform based on these principles, which has helped create more than 300,000 jobs and turned North Carolina’s economy into one of the fastest growing in the entire nation. I look forward to working closely with the President and Congressional leaders to fulfill our promises to deliver tax relief to hardworking families and business owners that will provide them with an even better chance to achieve the American Dream.

Today, the administration announced it will phase out the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA). I intend to introduce legislation addressing the legal status of undocumented children:  Immigration policy must be set through legislation, not executive orders. That was the fundamental flaw underpinning DACA and the reason it’s highly unlikely to survive a legal challenge. President Trump is wisely giving Congress a period of time to fulfill its responsibility to legislate and take long-term action to address the uncertainty facing undocumented children, who were brought to America through no fault of their own.  In the next week, I’ll be introducing legislation that will provide a fair and rigorous path for undocumented children to earn legal status by requiring them to be employed, pursue higher education, or serve in our Armed Forces. I know this kind of commonsense legislative fix can and should unite members of Congress, and I’ll be working closely with my colleagues on the path forward. It’s up to my Democratic colleagues to decide whether they want a permanent solution or to make this a political wedge issue. I hope they’ll choose bipartisanship.

We need to work together to come up with a commonsense and compassionate path forward for undocumented children. I plan to introduce legislation that will provide a fair and rigorous path for undocumented children to earn legal status.

I joined Swain County leaders, Congressman Mark Meadows and Secretary Zinke at the U.S. Department of the Interior for a major announcement helping solve a decades old problem that will benefit Swain County in North Carolina.  Read more about the announcement: http://bit.ly/2gQwAGF

My op-ed via Fox News Opinion:  "In the week ahead, I’ll be introducing legislation that will resolve the uncertainty facing undocumented children and young adults. This conservative solution would provide a rigorous, merit-based pathway for young undocumented immigrants to earn conditional legal status by requiring them to be employed, to pursue higher education, or to serve in our Armed Forces."

The SUCCEED Act, legislation that is a commonsense and merit-based solution for undocumented children to earn legal status if they work hard, follow the law, and pay their taxes, is earning bipartisan praise for its reasonable and realistic approach.
This week, I spoke on the Senate Floor about the need to pass tax reform for the American people. We need legislation that helps working families and creates jobs.

The SUCCEED Act, legislation that is a commonsense and merit-based solution for undocumented children to earn legal status if they work hard, follow the law, and pay their taxes, would be great for the health of the American economy.

I'm proud to introduce legislation with Senator Amy Klobuchar and Senator Chuck Grassley to aid in locating missing Autism and Alzheimer’s patients.   This legislation has a deep personal meaning for me, as I was a caregiver for my grandmother during her battle with Alzheimer’s disease. We should be moving heaven and earth to help families and caregivers reunite with loved ones who wander and disappear, and Kevin and Avonte’s Law can truly make a difference in preventing tragedies.

We can never repay our nation's veterans and their families for their service and sacrifice. As a U.S. Senator who represents over 790,000 veterans in North Carolina, I am committed to keeping our promise to the men and women who served and ensure they get the care and benefits they need and deserve.

As co-chair of the Senate Human Rights Caucus, I urged President Trump to address human rights concerns with the leaders of China, Vietnam, and the Philippines during his trip to Asia. The U.S. must remain committed to standing up for those oppressed throughout the world and raise concern with those violating human rights and democratic values.

My op-ed in The Hill on the need to protect veterans from the bad actors in the VA home loan program. Unfortunately, a small number of lenders are abusing the program by utilizing misleading advertising tactics and engaging in a practice known as “churning” – the refinancing of a home loan over and over again to generate fees and profits for lenders.  This should not be happening to veterans who earned these benefits.  As we celebrate Veterans Day, we should work to make sure this benefit is truly beneficial for veterans and their families.

On this Veterans Day, take an extra effort to thank a veteran and their family for their service to this great nation. We'll never be able to fully repay the debt that we owe them, but we can make a lot of installments as individual citizens to show our gratitude. As long as I'm in the U.S. Senate, I will continue to work on behalf of our veterans to ensure we fulfill the promises we made to them.

My statement on the Senate’s Tax Cuts and Jobs Act:  The Senate has taken a big step toward passing tax reform that will lead to bigger paychecks for hardworking Americans and stimulate wages and jobs. I look forward to advancing this legislation through an open process so we can fulfill the promise we made to the American people to overhaul and modernize our tax code. I urge my more independent-minded colleagues on the other side of the aisle to ignore the reflexive, partisan opposition of Democratic leaders and instead work in a bipartisan manner to provide much-needed tax relief to hardworking families.

"Freedom is not free, but the U.S. Marine Corps will pay most of your share." — Capt. J.E. ‘Ned’ Dolan   Happy 242nd Birthday, U.S. Marine Corps! North Carolina is the proud home to Camp Lejeune, Marine Corps Air Station Cherry Point, and Marine Corps Air Station New River.

I co-sponsored the Fix NICS Act with Senators John Cornyn (R-TX), Chris Murphy (D-CT), Tim Scott (R-SC), and Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) to ensure federal and state authorities comply with existing law and accurately report relevant criminal history records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS).

My statement after the Senate passed its tax reform proposal, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act:  The Senate voted to take us one step closer to historic tax reform that will lead to bigger paychecks for hardworking Americans, and will make our nation more competitive at the global level. In the coming days, differences between the House and Senate versions of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will be resolved and improvements will be made, and I’m confident the end result will deliver on our promise to provide much-needed tax relief for the American people.

I applaud President Trump for reaffirming our commitment to our greatest ally in the Middle East by recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, following through on years of advocacy on the part of leaders from both parties. The United States and Israel have a special relationship that is rooted in shared common principles and core values, and the President’s defining action will further strengthen the bond between our two great nations.

As co-chairs of the Senate Human Rights Caucus, U.S. Senator Chris Coons and I celebrate Human Rights Day to recognize the adoption of the historic Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirming the rights of individuals and setting the standard for human rights protections. We will continue to work on behalf of those who advocate for basic human rights and ensure that the United States continues to set the standard for promoting freedom across the world.

A lot of people say bipartisanship doesn't happen anymore. I wanted to share this interaction I recently had with U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren, who serves on the Senate Armed Services Personnel Subcommittee with me. We won't agree on everything, but we can find common ground to move our nation forward.

A well-deserved award for Amy Wright, owner of Bitty & Beau's Coffee in Wilmington! I had the privilege of visiting this coffee shop and seeing the positive impact she’s making in the lives of individuals with disabilities. Truly inspiring. Congratulations to the 2017 CNN Hero of the Year! #CNNHeroes

Amy Wright, owner of Bitty & Beau's Coffee was named CNN Heroes 2017 Hero of the Year for her work on behalf of individuals with disabilities. The Wright family and the entire team at Bitty & Beau's are an inspiration to so many. Congrats on a well-deserved honor. #CNNHeroes

Today is a big win for American families and the American economy. The Senate passed tax reform legislation that fulfills a long-standing promise to deliver tax relief that benefits hard-working Americans across our nation. Starting early next year, most North Carolina families will notice bigger paychecks as the federal government withholds less of their hard-earned money because of newly lowered tax rates and a significantly larger standard deduction. This historic legislation also provides a major boost to American businesses and makes our private sector even more competitive at the global level, which in turn will lead more jobs, higher wages for workers, and stronger economic growth.
NA

This week, I attended the swearing-in ceremony at the Pentagon of my former Senior Advisor Robert Wilkie as Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness. There is no one more qualified to work on behalf of our men and women in uniform and their families.  Robert is a native of Fayetteville, NC: http://bit.ly/2BOp6u9

Susan and I want to wish you and your family a Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays. My family has been blessed this year with the arrival of our first granddaughter, Sawyer, and look forward to celebrating the holidays with our family. While you enjoy the holiday season with your loved ones, please remember the men and women of our nation’s military and first responders for their service and sacrifice keeping our country and communities safe. I hope you all have a wonderful end to 2017 and I look forward to connecting with you in 2018. Merry Christmas and God bless.

I'm glad to see the Senate unanimously pass Kevin and Avonte’s Law, bipartisan legislation which will support training for caregivers to prevent and respond to missing individuals with Alzheimer’s disease, autism, and related conditions.
North Carolina is proof that successfully enacting tax reform reaps tremendous rewards: more growth, more jobs, more businesses and more revenue.

In 2017, as chairman of the Senate Armed Services Subcommittee on Personnel, I worked on a bipartisan basis to oversee U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) personnel policies, including compensation, benefits, education and healthcare for servicemembers, their families, and DoD civilian employees.

During my first three years as a member of the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs, I have worked across the aisle to expand education and job opportunities for veterans and have worked to reform the VA to assure they are getting the healthcare they need and deserve.
